Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Critical Infrastructure Disruption and the Food Distribution Network: The Implications for Food Security Following a Natural Disaster

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Food security in the form of access to nutritional and affordable food is a chronic problem for a percentage of American households in normal times and this percentage can dramatically increase after a natural disaster as local retailers and food banks struggle to meet the needs of their customers and clients. Such was the case after Hurricane Harvey made landfall on the evening of August 25, 2017 along the middle of the Texas coast. During the next five days it dropped unprecedented amounts of rainfall throughout northeastern sections of the Texas coast generating extensive flooding, massive power and water system failures, displacing hundreds of thousands of households, and disrupting local food retailers and food banks. Unfortunately, very little systematic research exists on the consequences of disaster events for food retailers and food banks. This research will address this deficiency by investigating the consequences of Hurricane Harvey's impacts on local food retailers and food aid agencies. The data captured will inform interdisciplinary models of community resilience. Furthermore, results from this project will encourage and inform local, state, and national policies that address chronic and acute food-security issues; thereby reducing vulnerabilities and enhancing the resiliency of our nation's food distribution network. Findings from this research will also be incorporated directly into graduate and undergraduate courses on community resilience, planning methods and measures, and disaster recovery and mitigation.

This project will gather data on the consequences of direct damage to an establishment's physical structure and inventory, temporary and permanent loss of staff and employees, and the disruption of critical infrastructure systems (transportation, energy, water, and communications) from businesses and organizations comprising local food distribution networks. The project will assess the relative influence of these impacts for business/agency continuity and survival and for changes in local food distribution networks. To accomplish these goals, this project will conduct in-depth structured and semi-structured interviews with food retailers and food aid agencies in three counties -- Galveston, Harris, and Jefferson -- heavily impacted by Hurricane Harvey's flooding. Together the study area has more than 3,500 food retailers and three food banks that serve over 270 food pantries. A representative random sample of both large and small food retailers and non-profit food pantries operating in both impacted and non-impacted areas and serving populations of varying levels of food security will be surveyed. Quantitative models assessing: 1) the relative consequences of direct damage and infrastructure disruption for business failure and disruption and 2) changes to local food distribution infrastructure networks and the potential consequences for community food security will be developed utilizing these data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Food insecurity is a chronic problem in the U.S. that annually affects over 40 million people under normal conditions. This reality dramatically worsens after a disaster as retailers and food banks struggle to meet local needs. Food supply disruptions exacerbate the situation precisely when large numbers of people are thrust into disaster-related food insecurity. This problem was experienced by Southeast Texas when Hurricane Harvey made landfall on the Texas Gulf Coast in August 2017. The storm disrupted food distribution across the region due to inaccessible roadways, non-functioning bridges and infrastructure, and unstable electrical and water service.
This project has collected systematic research on the consequences of disaster events for food retailers and food bank operations. This research specifically examined the food retail and aid landscape after Hurricane Harvey in 2017. This project lays the foundation to understand how Hurricane Harvey affected the local food aid environment both spatially and quantitatively. 
The major goal of this project was to collect systematic data on links between interdependent critical infrastructure systems (ICISs) and food security. The project empirically investigated the consequences of Hurricane Harvey’s impacts to local food distribution networks in coastal communities in Texas. The objectives were to gather systematic data on the consequences of direct damage to an establishment’s physical structure, loss of staff or employees, and the disruption to critical infrastructure systems (transportation, energy, water, and communications) for the businesses and organizations that comprise local food distribution networks and ultimately for network operation.The significant results of the project included the design, implementation, data collection and processing of three survey efforts. The first survey of food aid agencies was conducted online. The online surveys integrated data collected from the Southeast Food Bank which help support and promote the survey. The second survey of food retailers in three Texas counties Harris, Jefferson, and Orange. Stores from across the region had a set chance of being selected. The project ensured that stores in low-income neighborhoods that had a greater risk of flooding were represented in the survey. The third survey of each store’s nutrition environment consisted of an assessment of the nature and quality of food within each food retailer. The nutrition environment survey provides critical information on the types of food items available within each store and ultimately in neighborhoods/parts of a community. Primary data collected from communities impacted by natural hazards is critical for conducting and expanding research. The collection of these data require skills in survey design and sample design, as well as data skills related to data entry, data cleaning, data archiving, and data analysis. This project has made a significant impact in terms of advancing these foundational techniques among the students and PIs on this project. The primary data collected by this project relates specifically to food access and infrastructure disruption after Hurricane Harvey, this data was collected shortly after the event which helped to increase the reliability and validity of data that would not be available had the data collection happened many years after the event.
The data captured by this RAPID will help inform interdisciplinary resiliency modeling being undertaken in the broader hazards community. Furthermore, findings made possible by these data collected can be vital for informing and shaping local, state, and national policy to address chronic and acute food security issues emerging from natural hazards and disasters.
